intro: Chaerophyllum aromaticum, commonly known as sweet cicely, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbel-shaped flowers. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are finely divided and emit a mild, sweet scent when crushed, contributing to its common name. Sweet cicely is often cultivated for its ornamental value and as a source of edible leaves and seeds.
